Yes, there are several workshops and schools in the Caucasus region where people can learn how to create traditional costumes and other handmade goods. These schools and workshops often focus on preserving traditional techniques and promoting local craftsmanship.

For example, in Georgia, the Art Palace in Tbilisi offers courses in traditional embroidery and other handicrafts. The Georgian National Museum also offers workshops on traditional metalwork, weaving, and other techniques.

In Armenia, the Tumo Center for Creative Technologies offers courses in traditional Armenian costume design, as well as classes on traditional dance, music, and other cultural practices.

In Azerbaijan, the State Museum of Azerbaijani Carpet and Applied Art offers workshops on traditional carpet weaving, embroidery, and jewelry-making.

Additionally, there are many private instructors and artisans throughout the Caucasus region who offer courses on traditional costume design and production.

If you're interested in learning more about traditional costume design and production in the Caucasus region, I would recommend researching specific schools and workshops in each country, as well as reaching out to local artisans and experts.
